front.reference:
Tetrahedron Letters No.16, pp. 1091-1099, 1965. Pergamon Press Ltd
Printed in Great Britain.

docTitle.titlePart: LAURENCIN, A CONSTITUENT FROM LAURENCIA SPECIES'

byline.docAuthor: Toshi Irie, Minoru Suzuki and Tadashi Masamune

byline.affiliation: Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Hokkaido University,

front.div:
An investigation of constituents from Laurencia glandulifera,
Kiit.zing,* led to the isolation of a compound containing bromine, which
was designated laurencin. In the present paper we wish to report that
formula (I) is the most favorable structure for the compound.
Laurencin (I), m.p. 73-74' (methanol) and [d]i3 +70:2' (in chloroform),
was obtained in 0.035% yield by chromatographic purificatior of the neutral
fraction from methanol extracts, and was analyzed for C H 0 Br (Found:
17 23 3
C, 57.42, 57.31; H, 6.54, 6.40; Br, 22.15; mol. wt. 354 and 356, from the
mass spectrum). The infrared spectrum suggested the presence of a termina
methine ( 3zio1
3285 and 2100 Cm-l), an acetoxyl (1735 and 1230 cm-')
and an ether group (1168 and 1080 cm-l), and trans and &
double bonds
(3040, 950 and 750 cm
-1
); and the ultraviolet spectrum (in ethanol),
a max
224 mi_' (E 16,400) ar.d hinfl
232 mp (E ll,OOO), showed the
presence of a conjugated diene or enyne. The N.M.R. spectrum3 (FIG. 1)
indicated the presence of four olefinic protons (the absorptions A, B and
C; abbr. H-A, H-B and H-C) and an acetoxyl group (K), and also suggested
the existence of an ethyl group (N, triplet). The latter was confirmed
by isolation of propionaldehyde on ozonization4 of I. However, only one
proton is involved in the absorption M and, therefore, two protons of the
methylene adjacent to the methyl group are not magnetically equivalent. 5
Another proton
